title: Superior Vena Cava Syndrome
author: Paul Frysh

content: Superior vena cava syndrome (SVCS) is when something -- usually a cancerous tumor -- blocks or pinches the superior vena cava, a major vein that carries blood from your chest, neck, and head to your heart .

sections.heading: Symptoms
content: One sign of superior vena cava syndrome is swelling in your face, arms, neck, head, or upper body. It may get worse when you bend forward or lie down. You might start to cough or have trouble breathing .
Less common symptoms include:
bullets: Trouble swallowing
Coughing up blood
Fluid buildup in arms
Chest pain
Bluish skin (from lack of oxygen)
Scratchy voice and other vocal changes
Horner's syndrome : A smaller pupil, sagging eyelid, and little or no sweat on one side of your face

Noncancerous conditions that can cause superior vena cava syndrome include:
bullets: Lung cancer
Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
Cancers that spread to your chest
Hodgkin's lymphoma
Primary leiomyosarcomas
Plasmacytomas
A tumor in the chest could push on the superior vena cava vein.
A tumor might grow into the vein and block it.
Lymph nodes near the vein may start to swell or enlarge because of cancer, and so pinch or push on it.
Cancer can cause a blood clot in the superior vena cava.
Blood clots resulting from problems with a pacemaker or a catheter (a flexible tube that goes into a vein)
Mediastinal fibrosis: Scarring in the area between your lungs
Blood vessel diseases like aneurysms, vasculitis, or arteriovenous fistulas
Infections such as tuberculosis , syphilis , or histoplasmosis
Noncancerous tumors including dermoid cysts , teratomas, and thymomas
Pericarditis : Inflammation of the sac around your heart

sections.heading: Diagnosing Superior Vena Cava Syndrome
content: Your doctor will do a series of imaging tests that take pictures of your insides to try and figure out if you have SVCS. These include:

The doctor may use a special X-ray process called venography. They’ll inject a dye into your vein before they take the image. This provides more detail about the type and location of the blockage in your vein.
In many cases, SVCS could be an early sign of cancer. Tests that could help your doctor diagnose cancer include:
bullets: Chest X-ray
Ultrasound
CT scan
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Sputum cytology: Collecting and analyzing of mucus from your lungs
Biopsy : Removing of a tiny bit of a lymph node or tumor to check it for cancer
Bronchoscopy: Using a camera on a tube that goes down your throat to look inside your lungs
Thoracotomy : Surgery to examine or make repairs inside your chest

sections.heading: Treatment
content: Treatment depends in large part on what’s causing your superior vena cava syndrome. If your symptoms are mild and the underlying cause isn’t serious, you may not need treatment right away.

content_blocks.text: Treatment depends in large part on what’s causing your superior vena cava syndrome. If your symptoms are mild and the underlying cause isn’t serious, you may not need treatment right away.

content: Often SVCS improves as a side effect of cancer treatment such as chemotherapy or radiation . For example, as the tumor gets smaller, it may push less on the superior vena cava.
Other treatments might include:
bullets: Corticosteroids to lessen swelling
Diuretic medications that get rid of extra fluid
Thrombolysis to break up a blood clot in the vein
Opening up the vein to help blood flow with tube-like “ stent ”
Surgery to bypass the blockage
